description.en: Although kaonic atoms provide valuable information concerning the K--nucleus interaction at low energies, they cannot fully determine the K--nucleus optical potential. We demonstrate that K- nuclear bound states, if they exist, can be useful in investigating the K--nucleus interaction, especially in the interior of the nucleus. In order to show this possibility, we calculate the double differential cross sections for (K-,p) using the Green function method.

Although kaonic atoms provide valuable information concerning the K--nucleus interaction at low energies, they cannot fully determine the K--nucleus optical potential. We demonstrate that K- nuclear bound states, if they exist, can be useful in investigating the K--nucleus interaction, especially in the interior of the nucleus. In order to show this possibility, we calculate the double differential cross sections for (K-,p) using the Green function method.

paper_title.en: Effects of baryon resonances on nucleon-nucleon interactions in a quark model

description.en: Nucleon-nucleon S-wave scattering is studied by using the resonating group method, which includes not only the nucleon and Delta but also their excited states. As quark-quark interactions, the one-gluon-exchange and one-pion-exchange potentials are employed with phenomenological confinement potential. Compared with the N and Delta, coupling effects induced by excited-state baryons are small. (C) 2000 Published by Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Baryon resonances in a constituent quark model

description.en: The role of pseudoscalar mesons in the dynamical properties of baryon resonances is examined by means of the constituent quark model with meson-quark coupling. Since resonance properties are closely related to meson-baryon scatterings, it is important to include reaction processes as well as mass spectra in the analysis. The isobar model is employed to properly extract information of baryon resonances from reaction amplitudes. Prominent features of resonance spectra are reproduced fairly well by taking account of baryon self-energies due to meson-quark coupling. Several problems remained in the static quark model of baryons, e.g. Lambda(1405)-Lambda(1520) mass difference, are also studied. Brief comments on some improvements of the present model are given.

paper_title.en: Baryon resonances in a constituent quark model

description.en: The role of pseudoscalar mesons in the dynamical properties of baryon resonances is examined by means of the constituent quark model with meson-quark coupling. Since resonance properties are closely related to meson-baryon scatterings, it is important to include reaction processes as well as mass spectra in the analysis. The isobar model is employed to properly extract information of baryon resonances from reaction amplitudes. Prominent features of resonance spectra are reproduced fairly well by taking account of baryon self-energies due to meson-quark coupling. Several problems remained in the static quark model of baryons, e.g. Lambda(1405)-Lambda(1520) mass difference, are also studied. Brief comments on some improvements of the present model are given.

paper_title.en: Effects of baryon resonances on nucleon-nucleon interactions in a quark model (共著)

paper_title.ja: Nucleon resonances in the constituent quark model with chiral symmetry

paper_title.en: Nucleon resonances in a constituent quark model with chiral symmetry

description.en: The mass spectra of nucleon resonances with spin 1/2, 3/2, and 5/2 are systematically studied in a constituent quark model with meson-quark coupling, which is inspired by the spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry of QCD. Meson-quark coupling gives rise not only to the one-meson-exchange potential between quarks but also to the self-energy of baryon resonances, owing to the existence of meson-baryon decay channels. These two contributions are consistently taken into account in the present model. The gross properties of nucleon resonance spectra are reproduced fairly well, although the predicted mass of N (1440) is too large.
